items.title: SnNotSupportedException: SnLinq: ContentSet.Execute<TResult>
items.body:
We use queries like this with our project:
`SenseNet.ContentRepository.Content containerContent = SenseNet.ContentRepository.Content.All.FirstOrDefault(c => c.InTree(PortalContext.Current.Site.Path) && c.Type("ProjectContainer"));`

It'd worked safe and sound but after we've upgraded sn services from 7.0.2 to 7.1.1 the following exception appeared:
```
SnNotSupportedException: SnLinq: ContentSet.Execute<TResult>
   at SenseNet.ContentRepository.Linq.ContentSet`1.Execute[TResult](Expression expression) in E:\BuildAgent\_work\63\s\src\ContentRepository\Linq\ContentSet.cs:line 205
```

items.title: Reducers ids create content success payload doesn't have result property

Loginstate doesn't go to Pending state
items.body: After `'USER_CHANGED'` the state set to Unauthenticated. After dispatching login from actions `'USER_LOGIN_LOADING'` doesn't change the state to pending. I expect the loginstate to be pending once it is in a loading state.

items.title: Add types to CreateStoreOptions
items.body:
CreateStoreOptions doesn't have types added to the properties. Please add types to them so intelisense can work better.

```
export interface CreateStoreOptions {
    rootReducer,
    repository,
    middlewares?,
    persistedState?
}
```

items.title: Add redux devtools by default or a way to add that to the createSensenetStore
items.body:
Right now there is no way to add [redux-devtools](https://github.com/zalmoxisus/redux-devtools-extension) to the store.

    const store = createStore(
        options.rootReducer,
        {},
        applyMiddleware(...middlewareArray),
    )

redux-devtools should wrap the `applyMiddleware()` method.

- WRONG: public	Abstract class	SenseNet.Tools	SenseNet.Diagnostics.Analysis	Transformer`1

items.title: Loading settings in elevated mode
items.body:
Currently we populate the settings tree cache in the name of the current user, which is invalid, because sometimes that user does not have enough permissions for _all the content to load_.

All (?) tree caches should be loaded in **elevated mode**, in a `SystemAccount` block.

#### Solution options
1. elevate in the base TreeCache class (singleton Instance property)
2. elevate in the LoadItems implementations in derived classes

#### Acceptance
- [ ] backport to SN6 and notify the CF team

items.title: NullReference exception in TreeCache
items.body:
In some cases (under a heavy load, when workspaces are created in parallel and the settings cache gets invalidated many times) a nullreference exception is thrown in the _TreeCache_ class ([link-to-line](https://github.com/SenseNet/sensenet/blob/7aef9cf685ccfa30e8c599c7f8f48f779f332bfd/src/ContentRepository/TreeCache.cs#L122)), when accessing the singleton Instance.

#### Possible cause
The internal variable may become null because the invalidation in the _InvalidatePrivate_ method happens **outside of a lock block**.

#### Solution options
1. simplify the code using a Lazy variable (_preferred_)
2. or lock the invalidation too

#### Acceptance

- [ ] backport to SN6 and notify the CF team

items.title: Patching in the cloud
items.body:
The current _SnAdmin_ tool will not be sufficient in a cloud environment. We should discuss the pros and cons of the different options for patching in the cloud.

#### Considerations
- web folders and db are updated differently than in an on-premise solution
- we do not have access to the actual web folder in the cloud, we can patch only the dev machine. After that the developer will _publish_ the new web folder to the staging and live environments.
- currently old and new dlls and the content repository can be 'incompatible' in many ways (old/new CTDs, missing handlers or other dlls) - can we _reduce the chance_ of this so that old and new app domains can connect to the _same database_?

items.title: SnTrace providers
items.body:
Currently we write trace messages to the file system. In a cloud environment this is not the best solution. We should keep the file system writer as the default, but let 3rd party developers create custom providers.

- [x] refactor the current solution to an independent package: **SnFileSystemTraceProvider**
- [x] create a new built-in trace provider that writes to the console: **SnConsoleTraceProvider**
- [x] documentation

A new cloud-friendly provider that sends messages to a _remote service_ is a separate issue.

items.title: SN6-SN7 upgrade package v0.1
items.body:
Assemble an upgrade package that can be executed _potentially_ on a real SN6 instance, not just the default installation.

- [x] configuration sections and values are updated (in web and snadminruntime config)
- [x] fake package records are updated in SQL scripts to the latest package versions

items.title: Logging in the cloud
items.body:
Currently we have a dependency on **Enterprise Library** and its _logging configuration_.

- [ ] find a more modern logging service with similar flexibility (that supports log levels, properties)
- [ ] create a logging provider (_IEventLogger_ implementation) _prototype_ for this service
- [ ] remove EntLib dependency from the core product and move the current implementation to a standalone package

#### Acceptance

- the prototype works locally
- the system works as before using the outsourced entlib logging provider

items.body: Break permissions and add full control for admins and owners on the Profiles container if it is generated by code.

items.title: Make the OnMessageReceived virtual method proteced
items.body: The _OnMessageReceived_ method is virtual so it can be overridden - but currently only inside the assembly. By adding the ```protected``` modifier we let 3rd party devs to create a custom cluster channel implementation that reuses the logic in the built-in base class.

items.body: Remove the project's dependency on the old _EventLog_api and use the new api available in .Net Standard (EventSource?).

items.title: Remove configuration dependency
items.body: Remove the project's dependency on the old _ConfigurationManager_ api and use the new mutation available in .Net Standard.

items.title: Road to .Net Standard
items.body: Convert sensenet code base piece-by-piece to support **.Net Standard** so that sensenet packages may be used from a .Net Core _and_ a .Net Framework application.

items.title: ContentQuery LINQ StartsWith issue
Package sandbox directory
items.body:
Currently the sandbox folder (called _run_) is created next to the package that is executed. If packages are stored in multiple folders all over in the file system (instead of a single place), these run folders are created in many different places.

### Possible solutions
1. configure a fixed sandbox folder path
2. always create the sandbox folder in the parent of SnAdmin.exe instead of the parent of the current package
3. ~always copy the package into the Admin folder and execute it from there~

items.title: [Packaging] Edit assembly bindings in config files
items.body:
Custom step: add or edit assembly bindings in web.config and snadminruntime config files.

- Should work with the **SN6** codebase
- one step adds/changes a single _dependentAssembly_ node
- there is a previous custom step that is capable of **editing**, maybe we can extend that with the add feature :  $/SenseNet/Tools/CustomPackages/SimpleCustomSteps/UpdateAssemblyBinding.cs
- if there is an existing binding: replace only if the existing version is _lower_

```xml
<CustomSteps.UpdateAssemblyBinding name="Microsoft.Owin" publickey="12314234345" newVersion="3.0.1"/>
```

items.title: Migrate configurations during sn6-sn7 upgrade
items.body:
Config sections changed since sn6 significantly.

- [x] Web.config
- [x] Tools\SnAdminRuntime.exe.config

The step can be something like this:
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Package>
  ...
  <Steps>
    <EditConfiguration>
      <Move>
        <Element sourceSetion="section1"
                 targetSection="sensenet/section2" />
        <Element sourceSetion="appSettings"
                 sourceKey="asdf"
                 targetSection="sensenet/section3"
                 default="42" />
        <Element sourceSetion="appSettings"
                 sourceKey="LuceneActivityTimeoutInSeconds"
                 targetSection="sensenet/indexing"
                 targetKey="IndexingActivityTimeoutInSeconds" />
        ...
      </Move>
      <Delete>
        <Element section="appSettings"
                 key="RestoreIndex" />
        ...
      </Delete>
    </EditConfiguration>
  </Steps>
</Package>```

 - [ ] Create documentation for the public components of *sn-document-viewer-react*
 - [ ] Check for for compatibility with Parcel

items.title: Research: parceljs
items.body:
We should check if we can change our packaging / bundling pipeline from *webpack* and *create-react-app* to [parceljs](https://parceljs.org/).

### Tasks
 - [x] Compare dependencies with
     - [x] a manually built webpack bundle
     - [x] a package created with create-react-app
 - [x] Compare usage 
     - [x] dev. server functionality
     - [x] compiling times
     - [x] support for environment variables
 - [x] Check compatibility with CI tools
 - [x] update and test Parcel on some complex packages
     - [x] sn-document-viewer-react) 
     - [x] sn-community-app
 - [x] summarize
 - [ ] ~give an estimate for the remaining packages~

### Summary
 - Migrating a webpack or create-react-app project is quite easy
 - There aren't major differences in terms of speed, functionality or bundle size
 - There where issues with incremental bundling vs. sourcemapping
 - There where issues with async operators vs. Babel polyfills
 - We shouldn't migrate our projects from webpack to parcel right now
